About.title: About ASKKSA
About.description: It was in April of the year 2000 that ASKKSA, Associação Shotokan Kokusai Karate de Santo António, was established in Funchal. The goal of this formation was not only to relaunch the discipline to new levels but also to integrate it within the legal and sporting framework of the Autonomous Region of Madeira. The ASKKSA Association is affiliated with FNK-P (National Karate Federation – Portugal) and AKRAM (Karate Association of the Autonomous Region of Madeira) and is recognized by the DRJD (Regional Directorate of Youth and Sports).

instructors.title: An Elite Team
instructors.subtitle: ASKKSA is proud to have a highly qualified team of instructors, proven and with numerous national and international certifications.

dojos.title: Our Dojos
dojos.subtitle: We currently have two training spaces in Funchal and provide technical support to the Câmara de Lobos Sports Club.

meta.title: History of Karate-do | ASKKSA Shotokan Karate Madeira
meta.description: Discover the rich history of Karate-do, from its origins in Okinawa to its modernization and rise in popularity as a renowned Japanese martial art worldwide.
meta.keywords: History of Karate, Karate-do, Budo, Gichin Funakoshi, Shotokan, Kihon, Kumite, Kata, Okinawa, ASKKSA

introduction.text: Karate or karate-do is a form of budo (the way of the warrior). A Japanese martial art that originated in Okinawa and was introduced to the main islands of the Japanese archipelago in 1922. Karate emphasizes striking techniques (such as punches and kicks) over grappling techniques.

threePillars.title: The Three Pillars of Practice
threePillars.subtitle: Karate practice can be divided into three main parts:

kihon.title: Kihon (基本):
kihon.description: The study and repetition of basic movements, the foundation of all technique.

kumite.title: Kumite (組手):
kumite.description: Means "fighting" and is the practical application of techniques with a partner, which can be performed in a defined or free form (randori).

kata.title: Kata (型):
kata.description: Means "form" and is a sequence of movements that simulates a fight against imaginary enemies, essential for the development of technique and spirit.

origins.title: Origins and Evolution
origins.content: Originally, the word "karate" was written with ideograms meaning "Chinese hand" (唐手), reflecting the influence of the Tang dynasty. Today, the most common meaning is "empty hand" (空手), and Karate-do translates as "the way of the empty hand". It is believed that the art is a fusion of Chinese fighting techniques, brought to Okinawa by merchants, with the native fighting art of Okinawa, known as Te (hand).
origins.matsumura: In 1820, master Sokon Matsumura merged the local styles (Shuri-te, Naha-te and Tomari-te), but it was his own students who, by adding and subtracting techniques, created new variants. It was Gichin Funakoshi, a student of one of Matsumura's disciples, who introduced and popularized Karate in the main islands of Japan.

modernization.title: Modernization in Japan
modernization.funakoshi: Funakoshi was responsible for changing the writing of the name to "empty hand", a way to integrate the art into Japanese budo culture and distance it from its foreign origins during a period of strong nationalism. Karate was popularized and introduced in high schools before World War II.
modernization.transition: Like many Japanese martial arts, Karate made its transition to Karate-do in the early 20th century. The "do" (way) imbues the practice with elements of Zen Buddhism, sometimes called "Zen in motion". Modernization also included the adoption of the white uniform (keikogi) and colored belts to indicate rank, both popularized by Jigoro Kano, the founder of Judo.

meta.title: Karate Philosophy | Bushido, Niju Kun, Dojo Kun | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the philosophy of Shotokan Karate through Bushido, Niju Kun, and Dojo Kun. Ancient principles of discipline, respect, and self-control. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Karate Philosophy, Bushido, Niju Kun, Dojo Kun, Sensei Funakoshi, Karate Principles, Samurai, Code of Ethics, ASKKSA, Shotokan, Funchal, Madeira, Discipline, Respect

Philosophy.title: Karate Philosophy
Philosophy.introduction: The philosophy of Shotokan Karate is based on ancient principles that shape not only the technique but also the character of the practitioner. Discover the ethical and moral foundations that guide every karateka.

bushido.title: Code of Ethics – Bushido
bushido.description: The nine ethical principles inspired by the Samurai code: honor, loyalty, sincerity, courage, kindness, humility, justice, respect, and self-control.

nijuKun.title: Niju Kun – 20 Principles
nijuKun.description: The twenty principles developed by Sensei Gichin Funakoshi that form the philosophical foundation of all Karate practitioners.

dojoKun.title: Dojo Kun – 5 Maxims
dojoKun.description: The five fundamental maxims of Sensei Funakoshi for everyone who steps into a training space, the Dojo.

importance.title: The Importance of Philosophy in Karate
importance.description: The philosophy of Karate goes beyond physical techniques; it encompasses a moral and ethical code that guides practitioners both inside and outside the dojo. These ancient teachings form the foundation of each karateka’s personal and spiritual development.

meta.title: Bushido Code of Ethics | 9 Samurai Principles | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the Bushido code of ethics in Shotokan Karate. The 9 samurai principles: honor, loyalty, sincerity, courage, kindness, modesty, justice, respect, and self-control. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Bushido, Karate Code of Ethics, Samurai Principles, Karate Philosophy, Honor, Loyalty, Sincerity, Courage, Kindness, Modesty, Justice, Respect, Self-Control, ASKKSA, Shotokan, Funchal, Madeira

Bushido.title: Bushido Code of Ethics
Bushido.introduction: Bushido, or the "Way of the Warrior," is the samurai moral code of conduct that has been adapted for Shotokan Karate. This code represents the fundamental values that every practitioner must cultivate.
Bushido.description: The nine principles of Bushido form the ethical foundation of our practice, guiding character development both inside and outside the dojo. Each principle represents an essential virtue for personal and spiritual growth.

honor.name: Honor
honor.description: Personal dignity and moral integrity that guide all actions of the karateka

loyalty.name: Loyalty
loyalty.description: Faithfulness to principles, to the dojo, to instructors, and to training partners

sincerity.name: Sincerity
sincerity.description: Honesty with oneself and with others in all circumstances

courage.name: Courage
courage.description: Bravery to face challenges and to stand up for what is right

kindness.name: Kindness
kindness.description: Compassion and benevolence in the treatment of all beings

modesty.name: Modesty
modesty.description: Humility and simplicity, always recognizing there is much to learn

justice.name: Justice
justice.description: Moral righteousness and fairness in all decisions and actions

respect.name: Respect
respect.description: Consideration and reverence for oneself, for others, and for tradition

selfControl.name: Self-Control
selfControl.description: Mastery over one’s own emotions, impulses, and reactions

meta.title: Niju Kun – 20 Principles | Gichin Funakoshi | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the 20 fundamental principles of Shotokan Karate (Niju Kun) developed by Sensei Gichin Funakoshi. Philosophy and teachings for life. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Niju Kun, 20 Karate Principles, Gichin Funakoshi, Karate Philosophy, Teachings, Fundamental Principles, Traditional Karate, ASKKSA, Shotokan, Funchal, Madeira

NijuKun.title: Niju Kun – The 20 Principles
NijuKun.introduction: Sensei Gichin Funakoshi developed and refined twenty principles that should form the philosophical foundation of every Karate practitioner. He called these teachings *Niju Kun*.
NijuKun.description: These fundamental principles guide not only Karate practice but also how we should live our lives—with honor, respect, and discipline.

greeting.title: 1. Greeting
greeting.description: Karate begins with a bow and ends with a bow.

noOffense.title: 2. Non-Offensive
noOffense.description: There is no offensive attitude in Karate.

justice.title: 3. Path of Justice
justice.description: Those who practice Karate must follow the path of justice.

spiritDevelopment.title: 5. Spirit Development
spiritDevelopment.description: The development of spirit is the most important; technical skill is only a means to this end.

mentalControl.title: 6. Mental Control
mentalControl.description: Avoid losing your mental balance—control your mind.

lifeLongTraining.title: 8. Lifelong Training
lifeLongTraining.description: Karate training lasts a lifetime; it does not end with initiation.

applyKarate.title: 9. Apply Karate
applyKarate.description: Apply Karate in everything you do.

hotWater.title: 10. Hot Water
hotWater.description: Karate is like hot water—if you don’t keep heating it, it will cool down.

notBeDefeated.title: 11. Do Not Be Defeated
notBeDefeated.description: Do not think about winning—think about not being defeated.

strengthWeakness.title: 12. Strengths and Weaknesses
strengthWeakness.description: Victory depends on the ability to distinguish between strengths (*JITSU*) and weaknesses (*KYO*).

moveWithOpponent.title: 13. Move with the Opponent
moveWithOpponent.description: Move in harmony with your opponent.

sharpSwords.title: 14. Sharp Swords
sharpSwords.description: Imagine your opponent’s limbs are sharp swords.

millionOpponents.title: 15. Millions of Opponents
millionOpponents.description: For every man who leaves his house, there are a million opponents waiting.

artificialToNatural.title: 16. Artificial to Natural
artificialToNatural.description: At first, movements are artificial, but over time they become natural.

correctPractice.title: 17. Correct Practice
correctPractice.description: Practice what you’ve been taught correctly, knowing that application will always vary.

forceControl.title: 18. Control of Force
forceControl.description: Apply correctly: 1) Strength and weakness when using your power; 2) Expansion and contraction of the body; 3) Control of techniques in both slow and fast execution.

studyPractice.title: 19. Study and Practice
studyPractice.description: Always study, practice, and strive for improvement.

footer.title: Live the Principles
footer.message: These 20 principles of Niju Kun are more than rules for the dojo—they are a guide to living a life of integrity, respect, and continuous growth.

meta.title: Dojo Kun – 5 Maxims | Gichin Funakoshi | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the 5 fundamental maxims of the Dojo Kun developed by Sensei Gichin Funakoshi for all Karate practitioners. Essential principles for the dojo. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Dojo Kun, 5 Karate Maxims, Gichin Funakoshi, Dojo Philosophy, Dojo Commandments, Dojo Principles, Traditional Karate, ASKKSA, Shotokan, Funchal, Madeira

DojoKun.title: Dojo Kun – The 5 Maxims
DojoKun.introduction: Sensei Gichin Funakoshi developed and refined five maxims that he believed were essential for everyone who entered a training space—the Dojo. He called these commandments *Dojo Kun*.
DojoKun.description: These five fundamental maxims establish the moral and ethical principles that should guide all practitioners within the dojo, fostering an environment of respect, discipline, and personal growth.

character.title: HITOTSU JINKAKU KANSEI NI TSUTOMURU KOTO
character.description: Character (Strive for the perfection of character)

sincerity.title: HITOTSU MAKOTO NO MICHI O MAMORU KOTO
sincerity.description: Sincerity (Be faithful to the path of truth)

effort.title: HITOTSU DORYOKU NO SEISHIN O YASHINAU KOTO

selfControl.title: HITOTSU KEKKI NO YU O IMASHIMURU KOTO

footer.title: The Spirit of the Dojo
footer.message: These five maxims of the Dojo Kun are recited at the beginning and end of each training session, reminding us of the core values that should guide both our practice and our lives.

meta.title: Shotokan – 26 Katas | Gichin Funakoshi | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the 26 katas of the Shotokan style developed by Sensei Gichin Funakoshi. A lifetime of study and practice. Heian, Tekki, Bassai, Kanku. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Shotokan Katas, 26 Katas, Gichin Funakoshi, Shotokan Karate, Heian, Tekki, Bassai, Kanku, Traditional Kata, ASKKSA, Funchal, Madeira

ShotokanKatas.title: Shotokan – 26 Katas
ShotokanKatas.introduction: The Shotokan style, founded by Sensei Funakoshi, currently includes 26 katas studied over a lifetime of training.
ShotokanKatas.description: Each kata represents a unique form of imaginary combat, preserving ancestral techniques and traditional Karate philosophy. Katas are the essence of Karate, combining movement, breath, and spirit.

kanku_dai.name: KANKU DAI (観空大)
kanku_dai.meaning: TO VIEW THE SKY (kan=look, ku=void/sky) – Long

footer.title: A Lifetime of Study
footer.message: The 26 Shotokan katas represent a complete universe of martial knowledge. Each kata has its own personality, history, and lessons to teach—offering a lifelong journey of learning.

meta.title: In the Dojo | Etiquette, Rules, and Traditions | ASKKSA Shotokan Karate Madeira
meta.description: Discover life inside the Shotokan Karate dojo. Salutation, rules, Japanese vocabulary, and the ranking system. Karate traditions and etiquette. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Karate Dojo, Karate Etiquette, Dojo Rules, OSS Salutation, Japanese Vocabulary, Karate Ranks, Traditions, ASKKSA, Shotokan, Funchal, Madeira

InDojo.title: In the Dojo
InDojo.introduction: In the Dojo, the heart of Karate, we practice and live by the principles that guide us. Here, tradition meets discipline, and every training session is an opportunity for personal growth.

salutation.title: Salutation
salutation.description: The salutation in Karate is an expression of sincerity (*SEIJITSU*), part of the ethical code of martial arts. It reflects a karateka who does not hide their ideals or feelings and who is true to themselves.

rules.title: Rules
rules.description: The dojo is the place where martial teachings are passed on to practitioners, and as such, it must be a place where seriousness and respect prevail.

vocabulary.title: Vocabulary
vocabulary.description: Since Karate is a martial art of Japanese origin, it is natural that many of the terms used in the dojo are in Japanese.

grades.title: Ranks
grades.description: Martial arts originating from Japan and Okinawa feature a variety of titles and ranking classes.

philosophy.title: Life in the Dojo
philosophy.description: The dojo is not just a place for physical training but a sacred space where spirit is cultivated, discipline is learned, and character is forged. Every element—from the salutation to the rules of etiquette—helps create an atmosphere of mutual respect and personal development.

meta.title: Salutation in Karate | OSS and Rituals | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the meaning of salutation in Shotokan Karate, the word OSS, and the rituals performed at the beginning and end of training. SEIJITSU, Mokuso, Seiza. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Karate Salutation, OSS, Karate Rituals, SEIJITSU, Mokuso, Seiza, Shomen ni Rei, Sensei ni Rei, ASKKSA, Shotokan, Funchal, Madeira, Dojo, Karate Etiquette

Salutation.title: Salutation
Salutation.introduction: Salutation in Karate is an expression of sincerity (*SEIJITSU*) and a core part of the martial arts ethical code. It reflects a karateka who is honest about their ideals and emotions and is true to themselves. Whether it’s a simple OSS, a bow to a training partner, or the formal start/end of class ritual, salutation carries deep meaning for those who live Karate in its purest form.
Salutation.description: Upon entering the dojo, we greet the Sensei and fellow students, recognizing the importance of mutual respect and discipline.

oss.title: The Word "OSS"
oss.origin: Derived from the Japanese word *Ossu-shinobu*, it is similar to our 'good morning' or 'good afternoon,' carrying meanings of patience, respect, and appreciation. Its tone can alter its meaning.
oss.creation: OSS was coined in the Japanese Naval Academy and is widely used in daily life to mean 'yes,' 'please,' 'thank you,' 'understood,' 'excuse me,' and more. In the Karate world, it’s used in nearly every situation requiring a response.
oss.importance: For a karateka, OSS is the most important word. It implies pushing oneself to the limits and enduring.
oss.meaning: In simpler terms, OSS means 'perseverance under pressure.' It’s a single word that encapsulates the essence of Karate philosophy.
oss.spirit: A true Karate practitioner cultivates the 'spirit of OSS.'

steps.meaning: Let us dedicate ourselves spiritually to this way of Karate
Thank you very much for the training, Sensei.

salutation.title: Formal Salutation
salutation.text: Practitioners should bow to the Sensei and their peers when entering and leaving the dojo.

meta.title: Dojo Rules | Etiquette and Conduct | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Learn the conduct and etiquette rules of the Shotokan Karate dojo. Behavior, respect, and Japanese traditions. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Dojo Rules, Karate Etiquette, Dojo Conduct, Respect, Japanese Traditions, Sensei, Karate Behavior, ASKKSA, Shotokan, Funchal, Madeira

DojoRules.title: Dojo Rules
DojoRules.introduction: The dojo is where martial arts teachings are passed on to practitioners, and as such, it must be a place where seriousness and respect prevail. At ASKKSA dojos, we follow traditional codes of conduct inspired by Japanese dojos—the birthplace of Karate.
DojoRules.description: It’s important that every karateka understands that, inside the dojo (and ideally in daily life), they should behave in accordance with the moral heritage of this martial art. The rules below should be understood and respected by all practitioners in our dojos.

responsibility.title: Responsibility and Care for the Space
responsibility.rule1: The DOJO is the responsibility of everyone who uses it. Feel free to give information to visitors, tidy up, or clean what’s dirty.
responsibility.rule2: Help however you can to improve the dojo environment.

hygiene.title: Personal Hygiene and Appearance
hygiene.rule1: Maintain personal hygiene and keep your Karate-Gi (uniform) clean.
hygiene.rule2: Always enter the training area with clean hands, feet, and trimmed nails.
hygiene.rule3: Do not wear jewelry (rings, earrings, bracelets, watches), strong perfumes, or any accessories that could interfere with your or others’ training.
hygiene.rule4: Do not walk around the dojo unless you are fully dressed.

entrance.title: Entering and Leaving the Dojo
entrance.rule1: Always bow while standing when entering or leaving the training area.
entrance.rule2: If you arrive after class has started, enter quietly, sit in *SEIZA*, and request permission from the highest-ranking instructor to join. Upon approval, bow and join the group.
entrance.rule3: If you must leave before the end of class, always ask the instructor or monitor for permission. NEVER leave during class without authorization.

behavior.title: Behavior During Class
behavior.rule1: Speak as little as possible during training.
behavior.rule2: When the instructor/monitor is demonstrating a technique, sit quietly and pay attention. If you don’t fully understand, observe others, try what you can, and wait for corrections.
behavior.rule3: If you must ask something, raise your right hand discreetly. Never shout for the instructor’s attention.
behavior.rule4: Sit in *SEIZA* or with legs crossed. Do not lean against the wall or sit in improper positions. Maintain good posture at all times.
behavior.rule5: Do not use your phone inside the dojo during class hours.
behavior.rule6: Even if you're outside the class area, keep quiet during training and don’t talk to those who are inside the class.

instructors.title: Relationship with Instructors
instructors.rule1: Inside the dojo, NEVER refer to instructors by their first name, even if you are close to them. The proper way is to address them as *Sensei* (teacher).
instructors.rule2: Train exactly as instructed. If you wanted to do things your own way, you wouldn’t need to come to the dojo.
instructors.rule3: Never argue with the instructor/monitor, even if another instructor has taught you something different. There are many ways to execute techniques, shaped by different experiences—this doesn’t mean one is wrong. Follow each instructor in their class to the best of your ability.

training.title: Training and Partner Interaction
training.rule1: Never refuse to train with someone chosen by the instructor.
training.rule2: Help those who need it, but never correct your partner unless you are the instructor/monitor or a black belt.
training.rule3: Never think you're disturbing others by not knowing how to perform a technique. We’re all learning and helping one another.
training.rule4: Respect senior students (especially black belts) and never argue about whether techniques are right or wrong. Remember, they did not earn their rank by accident.
training.rule5: Train with intensity and energy, but always respect your partner’s physical safety. Classes include people of different genders, ages, and physical conditions. While effort is important, so is adapting to your partner’s needs and goals. Respect their reasons for training.
training.rule6: Be aware of your surroundings. Adjust your intensity to your physical condition. Be responsible for yourself.
training.rule7: Do not skip any techniques—unless you are injured.

practical.title: Practical and Health Considerations
practical.rule1: If you have an injury or physical limitation, you must inform the instructor before class.
practical.rule2: Avoid attending classes if you have a contagious illness (airborne or contact-based).
practical.rule3: Do not delay or miss tuition payments. If you must miss class due to travel or illness, notify your instructor. Your financial contribution is essential to keep the dojo running.

meta.title: Japanese Vocabulary | Karate Terms | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Learn the essential Japanese vocabulary of Shotokan Karate. Numbers, counters, and common dojo terms. Hiragana, Katakana, Kanji. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Japanese Vocabulary, Karate Terms, Japanese Karate, Dojo, Japanese Numbers, Hiragana, Katakana, Kanji, ASKKSA, Shotokan, Funchal, Madeira

Vocabulary.title: Japanese Vocabulary
Vocabulary.introduction: Since Karate is a martial art of Japanese origin, it’s natural that many of the terms used in the dojo are Japanese. Although initially they might confuse practitioners, with continued training these words become part of every karateka's daily routine.
Vocabulary.description: It should be noted that Japanese uses three writing systems (Hiragana, Katakana, and Kanji) in daily life. To help new practitioners, below is the vocabulary most commonly used in karate dojos worldwide.

otherCounters.title: Other Counters
otherCounters.subtitle: hon (various types of objects, especially round and thin ones, but also techniques or groups of techniques, practice sessions, etc.)

vocabulary.title: Most Used Words
vocabulary.aihanmi: Relative position of two practitioners with the same leg forward
vocabulary.budo: Way of the warrior, martial arts
vocabulary.chi: Chinese word for vital energy, same as 'Ki'
vocabulary.gasho: Joining hands in front of the face to salute (Zen, Mokuzo, etc.)
vocabulary.gi: Uniform for practicing Budo composed of Uwagi (jacket), Zubon (pants), and Obi (belt)
vocabulary.gonosen: Tactic of letting the opponent attack first to counterattack
vocabulary.hakama: Wide pants worn over the gi in traditional martial arts (Kyudo, Kendo, Iaido, Aikido, etc.)
vocabulary.hikite: Pullback of the fist to the hip
vocabulary.horanokamae: Starting position of some katas where the hand covers the closed fist
vocabulary.ipponkumite: Exercises with partner with 1 attack 1 defense
vocabulary.jiyukumite: Controlled partner exercises where combat forms are free
vocabulary.joseki: Upper side, place of honor (in the dojo, the south wall, right of the main wall)
vocabulary.kamiza: Main wall of the dojo, east side, where the Tokonoma is located
vocabulary.kata: Training form, with or without partner, with predetermined technique sequences
vocabulary.kiai: Externalization of energy through a shout
vocabulary.kime: Concentration of physical and mental energy, decision
vocabulary.makikomi: Judo technique consisting of throwing the opponent by rolling
vocabulary.makiwara: Traditional straw target used for Karate-do or Kyudo training
vocabulary.midale: Karate-do training method consisting of continuous attacks and evasions
vocabulary.mokuso: Literally: not thinking. Concentration attitude during the start and end ceremonial practice of Budo
vocabulary.nukite: Attack with fingers together and extended
vocabulary.shimoza: West wall of the dojo, opposite Kamiza, where the students sit
vocabulary.shimoseki: North wall of the dojo, where non-practicing assistants may stay
vocabulary.shinai: Bamboo sword used in Kendo practice
vocabulary.shomenrei: Salute to the main wall of the dojo
vocabulary.shomentaishi: Salute directed to the main wall of the dojo
vocabulary.shuto: Knife hand (side of the little finger)
vocabulary.sokuto: Knife foot, side of the little toe
vocabulary.sutemi: Sacrifice of the body; techniques where the practitioner falls to throw the opponent
vocabulary.tatami: Japanese mat that covers the floor where Judo and Aikido are practiced
vocabulary.tomarite: Combat techniques originating from Tomari - Okinawa
vocabulary.tonfa: Agricultural instrument used in popular combat techniques
vocabulary.tori: The one who attacks, the executor
vocabulary.tsukuri: Contact, second phase of executing a Judo technique
vocabulary.uke: Attacker in paired practice; the one who executes the fall
vocabulary.ura: Movement performed by turning; the opponent's back
vocabulary.zen2: Japanese discipline, one of the branches of Buddhism

hiragana.title: Hiragana (ひらがな)
hiragana.description: Syllabic system used for native Japanese words

katakana.title: Katakana (カタカナ)
katakana.description: Syllabic system used for foreign words

meta.title: Karate Graduations | Kyu and Dan System | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Learn about the Shotokan Karate graduation system. Kyu, Dan, belt colors and symbolism. System founded by Jigoro Kano. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.
meta.keywords: Karate Graduations, Kyu Dan System, Karate Belts, Jigoro Kano, Belt Colors, Black Belt, Karate Ranking, ASKKSA, Shotokan, Funchal, Madeira

Graduations.title: Graduations
Graduations.introduction: Martial arts originating from Japan and Okinawa present a variety of titles and ranking classes. The current colored belt ranking system is the most accepted. Before this, many different methods were used to mark the various practitioner levels.
Graduations.description: The current system governing Karate using Kyu (class) and Dan (grade) was founded by Jigoro Kano, founder of Judo Kodokan. Kano was an educator and understood that many practitioners need immediate incentives after starting a martial art. The anxiety of this type of practitioner could not be satisfied by long-term goals alone.

system.title: Kyu and Dan Graduation System
system.founder: System founded by Jigoro Kano, founder of Judo Kodokan
system.purpose: Created to provide immediate incentives to practitioners beginning martial arts
system.motivation: Practitioners' anxiety could not be satisfied by long-term goals alone

symbolism.title: Color Symbolism
symbolism.description: In this color classification and on a symbolic level:
symbolism.white: White represents the purity of the beginner
symbolism.black: Black refers to the refined knowledge acquired over years of training

kyu.title: Kyu Graduations (Class)
kyu.description: Kyu graduations represent student levels, usually identified by colored belts
kyu.order: Descending count until the black belt

dan.title: Dan Graduations (Grade)
dan.description: In the black belt classification, the first is called 1st Dan, the second 2nd Dan, and so forth in ascending order up to 10th Dan, achievable only by exemplary masters who dedicated their entire lives to Karate.
dan.10: 10th Dan - Tenth grade - Achievable only by exemplary masters

timeline.title: Time of Dedication
timeline.description: The ranking system recognizes the time and dedication required for mastering Karate
timeline.journey: Each graduation represents a stage in the karateka's journey
timeline.mastery: The highest ranks are achievable only by masters who dedicated their entire lives to Karate

meta.title: News | Under Maintenance | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: ASKKSA news page under maintenance. Soon we will have updates about events, competitions, and activities of Shotokan Karate. ASKKSA Funchal, Madeira.

maintenance.title: Page Under Maintenance
maintenance.subtitle: We are working to serve you better
maintenance.description: Our news page is temporarily under maintenance. We are developing a new experience to share with you the latest news, events, and achievements of our association.

contact.title: Stay Informed
contact.description: While we work on the new page, you can follow our news through social media or contact us directly.

return.title: We’ll Be Back Soon
return.message: We appreciate your patience and understanding. The new news page will be available very soon with an improved experience.

Footer.mission: Tradition, discipline, and excellence in Shotokan Karate. Discover your inner strength through martial arts.
